goal.ch:
“By the time students graduate from college most will have spent 16 years in school. Given the many years we devote to it, this course begins by asking “what is education for?” Does schooling impart human capital that can be sold on the labor market later in life? Does it provide a signal of ability to potential employers but otherwise add little? Or does it simply socialize students to fit into modern society? What are the pecuniary and non-pecuniary returns to individuals and society? After covering these basic issues, this course explores the meaning and empirics of non-mainstream education. In particular, we study the Waldorf education. 
This course will focus primarily on articles from academic journals. Students will not be expected to understand all the mathematics or econometrics. Instead, our focus will be on grappling with the author’s key insights. We will read for enlightenment and entertainment rather than regurgitation and recitation.
 Human capital and signaling theories of education 
 Estimating the returns to education
 Are returns due to signaling or human capital?
 Some critiques of the standard view
 Non-pecuniary benefits of education
 Are there social returns to education?
 Education and economic growth
 Current issues
 Waldorf education“

outline.ch:
“1 ( 2/15 ) Get to know the students / Go through the syllabus / Different types of human capital
2 ( 2/22 ) 圖書館利用教育
3 ( 3/1 ) Assign papers and dates for presentations
Human capital and signaling theories of education:
1. Becker, G. (1962). Investment in human capital: A theoretical analysis. The Journal of Political Economy, 70(5), pp. 9–49.
2. Spence, M. (1972). Job Market Signaling. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 87(3), pp. 355–374.
4 ( 3/8 ) Estimating the returns to education:
1. Angrist, J. and A. Krueger (1991). Does Compulsory School Attendance Affect Schooling and Earnings? The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 106(4), pp. 979–1014.
2. Duflo, E. (2001). Schooling and Labor Market Consequences of School Construction in Indonesia: Evidence from an Unusual Policy Experiment. The American Economic Review, 91(4), pp. 795–813.
5 ( 3/15 ) Are returns due to signaling or human capital?
1. Lindsay, C. M. (1971). Measuring Human Capital Returns. The Journal of Political Economy, 79(6), pp.1195–1215.
2. Weiss, A. (1995). Human Capital vs. Signaling Explanations of Wages. The Journal of Economic Perspectives, 9(4), pp.133–154.
6 ( 3/22 ) Are returns due to signaling or human capital?
3. Murnane, R., J. Willett, and F. Levy (1995). The Growing Importance of Cognitive Skills in Wage Determination. Review of Economics and Statistics, 77(2), pp. 251–66.
4. Tyler, J., R. Murnane, and J. Willett (2000). Estimating the Labor Market Signaling Value of the GED. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 115(2), pp. 431–468.
7 ( 3/29 ) Some critiques of the standard view:
1. Goldsmith, A. H., J. R. Veum, and W. Darity (1997). The Impact of Psychological and Human Capital on Wages. Economics of Inquiry, 35(4), pp. 815–829.
2. Blaug, M. (1985). Where Are We Now in the Economics of Education? Economics of Education Review, 4(1), pp. 17–28.
8 ( 4/5 ) 本校職工共同暑休日放假1日
9 ( 4/12 ) Some critiques of the standard view:
3. Bowles, S., H. Gintis, and M. Osborne (2001). The determinants of earnings: A behavioral approach.Journal of Economic Literature, 39(4), pp. 1137–1176.
4. Bowles, S. and H. Gintis (2002). Schooling in Capitalist America Revisited. Sociology of Education, 75(1), pp. 1–18.
10 ( 4/19 ) Non-pecuniary benefits of education:
1. Haveman, R. and B. Wolfe (1984). Schooling and Economic Well-Being: The Role of Nonmarket Effects. The Journal of Human Resources, 19(3), pp. 377–407.
2. Oreopoulos, P. and K. G. Salvanes (2011). Priceless: The Nonpecuniary Benefits of Schooling, The Journal of Economic Perspectives, 25(1), pp. 159–184.
11 ( 4/26 ) Are there social returns to education?
1. Moretti, E. (2004). Estimating the social return to higher education: evidence from longitudinal and repeated cross-sectional data. Journal of Econometrics, 121(1-2), pp. 175–212.
2. Sand, B. M. (2013). A Re-examination of the Social Returns to Education: Evidence from U.S. Cities. Labour Economics, 24, 97-106.
12 ( 5/3 ) Education and economic growth:
1. Woo, J. H. (1991). Education and Economic Growth in Taiwan: A Case of Successful Planning. World Development, 19 (8), pp. 1029-1044.
2. Krueger, A. and M. Lindahl (2001). Education for Growth: Why and For Whom? Journal of Economic Literature, 39(4), pp. 1101–1136.
3. Pritchett, L. (2001). Where Has All the Education Gone? The World Bank Economic Review, 15(3), pp. 367–391.
4. Cohen, D. and M. Soto (2007). Growth and human capital: good data, good results. Journal of Economic Growth, 12(1), pp. 51–76.
13 ( 5/10 ) Current issues
14 ( 5/17 ) Current issues
15 ( 5/24) Speaker
16 ( 5/31 ) Waldorf education
1. Easton, Freda (1997). Educating the Whole Child, “Head, Heart, and Hands”: Learning from the Waldorf Experience. Theory into Practice, 36 (1), pp. 87-94.
2. Nicholson, David W. (2000). Layers of Experience: Forms of Representation in a Waldorf School Classroom. Journal of Education Curriculum Studies, 32 (4), pp. 575-587.
17 ( 6/7 ) Waldorf education
1. Dahlin, Bo (2010). A State-Independent Education for Citizenship? Comparing Beliefs and Values Related to Civic and Moral Issues among Students in Swedish Mainstream and Steiner Waldorf Schools. Journal of Beliefs ＆ Values: Studies in Religion ＆ Education, 31 (2), pp. 165-180.
2. Paschen, H (2014). Waldorf Education and Rudolf Steiner School as a Topic of Educational Science. Croatian Journal of Education, 16 (1), pp. 191–215.
3. Martzog, P., S. Kuttner, and G. Pollak (2016). A Comparison of Waldorf and Non-Waldorf Student-Teachers’ Social-Emotional Competencies: Can Arts Engagement Explain Differences? Journal of Education for Teaching: International Research and Pedagogy, 42 (1), pp. 66–79.
18 ( 6/14 ) Final Exam“
